title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SALT LAKE CITY — On a night when offensive artistry was at a premium, Kevin Johnson authored a masterpiece.

The Phoenix Suns’ veteran point guard, defying the grind of a defensive battle, delivered a performance for the ages, carrying his team to a gritty 95-87 victory over the Utah Jazz. In a game where no other player cracked 20 points, Johnson’s transcendent 46-point explosion was not just the story of the game; it was the only story.

From the opening tip, it was clear KJ was operating on a different plane. He sliced through the vaunted Jazz defense with a ruthless efficiency, a one-man offensive system against a team known for its methodical execution. While Karl Malone labored for his 19 points and John Stockton managed 15, Johnson was a whirlwind of unstoppable drives and clutch jumpers. The Utah defense, designed to stifle, had no answer for the singular force wearing No. 7 in purple and orange.

The Suns, leaning heavily on their captain, saw only two other players—A.C. Green and Hot Rod Williams—reach double figures, combining for a mere 22 points. This stark contrast in scoring burden highlighted the sheer historic nature of Johnson’s night. He didn't just outscore the opposition; he *was* the offense, a solo symphony in a game of dissonant notes.

In the final moments, as the Delta Center crowd watched in stunned silence, the outcome was inevitable. The Utah Jazz weren't defeated by the Phoenix Suns; they were conquered by Kevin Johnson. Forty-six points—a number etched into the annals of both franchises—stood as a monument to individual brilliance on a night where it was all his team required.
